awd_titl_txt: Spectroscopic Probes of Molecular Structure and Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Patrick Vaccaro of Yale University to investigate subtle effects in the way molecules interact with light and with other molecules.  One of the two thrusts in the work supported by this award looks at the way light interacts with molecules with "handedness" -- for example, many molecules, especially biologically important molecules have non-superimposable mirror images, which is one kind of "handedness."  The spectroscopic methods being developed in the Vaccaro laboratory aim to discriminate between different handed isomers of these molecules, as well as providing accurate benchmarks for theorists interested in modelling this phenomena.  In the other thrust, the work will look at weakly interacting molecules in order to improve our understanding of the very subtle forces that molecules feel for each other.  Professor Vaccaro's research students will be trained in optical and vacuum science as well as instrument design and construction.  In an outreach project supported by this award, Professor Vaccaro and his students will work with students and teachers in the New Haven Public Schools. The Vaccaro research group is diverse, and has historically had a large number of female scientists. 

Professor Patrick Vaccaro and his research group will study an interesting set of spectroscopic systems.  In one set of experiments, Vaccaro and his group will extend their past work on the chiroptical spectroscopy of isolated molecules in the gas phase.  In the next phase of this work, the Vaccaro group will use cavity ringdown polarimetry to probe the electronic circular dichroism and electronic circular dichroism of some fairly complex chiral molecules in the gas phase, including molecules like (R) - norbornenone and the very weakly optically active species cyclopropane-1,2-d2.  This work benefits from the collaboration with a number of prominent theoretical groups.  New chiroptical investigations will look at chiral solutes dissolved in a rare-gas matrix.  These later studies hope to investigate the changes in chiroptical response for molecules in weakly perturbing solvents.  In a separate thrust, the Vaccaro group will investigate the weak interactions between aromatic molecules by studying benzene-tropolone dimers with a variety of spectroscopic methods, including two-color resonant four-wave mixing spectroscopy.

por.por_cntn:
Research conducted under the auspices of this NSF grant was designed to unravel the origins of molecular behavior by probing fundamental physical properties and chemical propensities through the synergistic use of modern experimental and theoretical tools. As detailed below, specific efforts focused on the phenomena of optical activity and non-covalent interactions, the manifestations of which form the crux of many technological and medical innovations.

The concept of chirality, whereby objects and interactions possess intrinsic handedness, permeates the fabric of science, playing pivotal roles in numerous processes of fundamental and technological importance. Of particular relevance for molecular science are the radically different chemical/biochemical reactivities displayed by enantiomeric (mirror-image) species, a claim bolstered by the fact that most modern pharmaceuticals are chiral with the mirror-image form often being ineffective or even harmful. The crucial task of determining the absolute configuration (or handedness) of a molecule demands stereospecific interactions with a chiral agent of known characteristics, as epitomized by the right-/left-circular polarization states of light which give rise to the phenomena collectively known as optical activity. Work performed in support of this grant strived to advance our basic understanding and practical applications of such chiroptical effects by combining novel laser-spectroscopic probes of judiciously selected chiral targets with complementary theoretical analyses. In addition to affording definitive benchmarks for critically assessing the ability of burgeoning optical-activity calculations to determine absolute stereochemical configuration, new paradigms for correlating the physicochemical properties of chiral species (e.g., molecular structure and electronic configuration as well as the effects of the surrounding environment) with the magnitude and sign of chiroptical response were uncovered.

Noncovalent interactions, as epitomized by the ubiquitous concepts of hydrogen bonding (whereby a hydrogen atom is shared between adjacent donor and acceptor sites in a molecular complex), are of critical importance throughout nature, being responsible for the forces that bind soft matter (e.g., biomolecular complexes) and condensed phases (e.g., water) as well as for the elementary transformations (e.g., proton transfer) that govern many chemical and biochemical reactions (e.g., enzyme catalysis). Work performed during this NSF grant enlisted novel linear/nonlinear spectroscopic probes to interrogate hydrogen bonding in model compounds judiciously selected to highlight key aspects of such phenomena. Particular emphasis was placed on proton-transfer events that are classically forbidden (due to potential-energy impediments) but nevertheless can take place with surprising efficiency by way of explicitly quantum-mechanical effects like tunneling (or barrier penetration). These efforts led to the first laser-spectroscopic identification and characterization of a low-barrier hydrogen bond in a neutral species -- an elusive, yet practically important, motif that resides at the cusp of the below-barrier (quantum tunneling) and above-barrier (classical transport) regimes for proton transduction. Several studies designed to explore competitive pathways for intermolecular and intramolecular noncovalent bonding were performed, with the detailed interpretation of emerging experimental measurements by complementary theoretical analyses serving to elucidate the structural and dynamical paradigms that regulate non-covalent coupling.

Graduate and undergraduate students participated in all aspects of NSF-supported activities -- ranging from the planning and execution of experimental measurements to the interpretation and dissemination of emerging results -- thus enabling them to hone the critical problem-solving, organizational, communication, and leadership skills needed to tackle substantial tasks. Recruitment of group members actively aspired to nurture greater ethnic, gender, and cultural diversity, engaging everyone in an notably interdisciplinary and collaborative environment that fostered their continuous scientific and professional development. Many emerging technologies of importance to U.S. socioeconomic prosperity rely heavily on such multidisciplinary expertise, as does the mounting need to ensure the security and defense of National interests. Therefore, a significant development of human resources, as embodied in the training of our future generation of scientists, engineers, and educators, was realized in addition to completion of programmatic research goals.
